title: Quiz: FQE February 2025 - Community Health
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Clinical Medicine & Surgery - Community Health (February 2025)

questions.question: Secondary prevention of disease involves:
questions.explanation: Secondary prevention focuses on early diagnosis and prompt treatment. Surveillance often involves active case finding and early detection, which fits this category. Immunization/Child spacing are Primary; Rehabilitation is Tertiary.
questions.hint: Think about early detection rather than prevention of onset or disability limitation.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE concerning community health?

options.text: Diagnosis is based on demographic data
History taking and examination is a key component
Treatment and rehabilitation forms part of implementation
Evaluation of health outcome is based on follow-up and assessment

questions.explanation: In Community Health, the 'patient' is the community. Diagnosis is made using vital statistics, demographic data, and epidemiological studies, unlike clinical medicine which uses individual history and exam.
questions.hint: Contrast the 'community' approach with the 'individual' clinical approach.

questions.question: A complete count of everyone alive at any one time within a stated geographical boundary is called:
questions.explanation: A Census is the total enumeration of a population at a specific time within a specific boundary. Civil registration is continuous (births/deaths).
questions.hint: This happens periodically (e.g., every 10 years) and counts *everyone*.

questions.question: The process where a community is fully involved in the identification of their problem is referred to as:
questions.explanation: Community diagnosis is the specific process of identifying and quantifying the health problems in a community, ideally involving the community members themselves.
questions.hint: This term parallels the clinical process of identifying a patient's illness.

questions.question: A frequency measure of disease usually used to record chronic disease is:
questions.explanation: Prevalence measures the total number of existing cases (old + new), making it ideal for chronic diseases with long durations. Incidence measures new cases (better for acute diseases).
questions.hint: Chronic diseases last a long time, so we count existing cases.

questions.question: Malaria endemicity where transmission occurs all the year round is classified as:
questions.explanation: Holoendemic malaria is characterized by intense, perennial (year-round) transmission, resulting in a high degree of immunity in the adult population.
questions.hint: Think of the prefix that implies 'whole' or 'entire' year transmission.

questions.question: Vitamin A deficiency is associated with:
questions.explanation: The classic clinical sign of VAD is Xerophthalmia (dry eyes) leading to night blindness and keratomalacia. Osteomalacia and Rickets are Vitamin D deficiencies.
questions.hint: This vitamin is crucial for vision.

questions.question: Which of the following vaccines can be frozen?
questions.explanation: Measles, BCG, and OPV are freeze-stable (often kept frozen at national stores). Pentavalent and Tetanus (adsorbed vaccines) are freeze-sensitive and destroyed if frozen.
questions.hint: Live attenuated viral vaccines generally tolerate freezing better than adsorbed toxoids.

questions.question: Which of the following is a mechanical method of contraception?
questions.explanation: The Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) acts mechanically (and chemically) to prevent implantation. The other options are natural methods.
questions.hint: This involves a physical device inserted into the uterus.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a water-related (water-based) disease?
questions.explanation: Schistosomiasis is water-based because the intermediate host (snail) lives in water. Trachoma is water-washed. Amoebiasis and dysentery are water-borne.
questions.hint: The host (snail) lives in the water.

questions.question: Trachoma develops in four stages. Stage one (TF) is consistent with:

options.text: Follicles on the inside of the upper lid

questions.explanation: WHO grading 'TF' (Trachomatous Inflammation-Follicular) involves the presence of 5 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva. This is the active early stage.
questions.hint: Look for the word 'Follicle' in the stage name TF.

questions.question: Severe malaria includes any episode of slide-confirmed falciparum malaria with:
questions.explanation: Features of severe malaria include Renal failure (Blackwater fever), Severe Anemia (<5g/dl), Hypoglycemia (not Hyper), and Cerebral malaria.
questions.hint: This involves organ failure affecting the kidneys.

questions.question: Which of the following is a LATE symptom of pulmonary tuberculosis?

options.text: Productive cough for more than 2-3 weeks

questions.explanation: Hemoptysis (coughing up blood) is typically a sign of advanced tissue destruction (cavitation), making it a later symptom compared to the initial chronic cough and night sweats.
questions.hint: It indicates severe tissue damage and bleeding.

questions.question: The MEAN is the best measure of central tendency because:

options.text: It is the most frequently occurring observation
It uses all the observations in the data

questions.explanation: The mean takes into account the value of every single observation, making it the most information-rich measure of central tendency for normally distributed data.
questions.hint: It doesn't leave any data point out of the calculation.

questions.question: In population health, a characteristic that takes on different values in different populations, persons, or places is called a:
questions.explanation: A Variable is any characteristic, number, or quantity that can be measured or counted and is capable of varying (changing) from one individual/group to another.
questions.hint: Because it 'varies'...

questions.question: Which one of the following is a DESCRIPTIVE epidemiological study design?
questions.explanation: Descriptive studies include Case Reports, Case Series, and Cross-sectional studies. Cohort is analytical. (Note: B is the best single answer for prevalence description, but D is also descriptive. B is usually the intended answer for 'study design' in this context).
questions.hint: It takes a snapshot of a population at one point in time.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a NON-PROBABILITY sampling method?
questions.explanation: Snowball sampling is a non-probability method where subjects recruit future subjects. B, C, and D are probability (random) methods.
questions.hint: This method relies on referrals from existing participants.

questions.question: A team of clinicians visited a primary school to screen all the teachers for visual impairment. Which type of disease screening is this?
questions.explanation: Selective (or Targeted) screening is applied to specific groups (e.g., teachers, factory workers) who may be at risk or are a convenient focus group, rather than the entire general population.
questions.hint: It targets a specific group (teachers) rather than everyone.

questions.question: A screening test that has the ability to correctly identify those who DO NOT have the disease is said to demonstrate:
questions.explanation: Specificity is the ability to correctly identify Negatives (those without disease). Sensitivity identifies Positives.
questions.hint: Think 'True Negatives'.

questions.question: The best common type of surveillance in humanitarian emergencies and communicable diseases is:
questions.explanation: In emergencies, lab confirmation takes too long. Syndromic surveillance (tracking symptom patterns like 'Acute Watery Diarrhea') provides an early warning system for rapid response.
questions.hint: It relies on clinical symptoms rather than lab confirmation.

questions.question: Coverage as a quality epidemiological indicator in assessing programme outcome measures:

options.text: The actual services received compared with the standards
The proportion of the target population that has received services
The population of the target population that can use the service
The number of services compared with total target population

questions.explanation: Coverage is defined as the number of people receiving service divided by the total target population.
questions.hint: It answers 'How much of the target group did we reach?'

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a form of graphical display of data?
questions.explanation: Tables are a form of tabular presentation, not graphical. Pie charts and Scatter diagrams are definitely graphs.
questions.hint: One of these arranges numbers in rows and columns, not images.

questions.question: Which one of the following processes is involved in the SECONDARY treatment stage of sewage?
questions.explanation: Secondary treatment is biological. The Activated Sludge process uses bacteria to break down organic matter. Disinfection is tertiary.
questions.hint: This process involves using bacteria to eat the waste.

questions.question: Which of the following hospital waste can be segregated and put in BLACK containers?
questions.explanation: Black bins are for General/Non-infectious waste (food, paper). Placenta goes in Red/Yellow. Ampules go in Sharps box.
questions.hint: Think of general domestic waste.

questions.question: Wastes that should NOT be incinerated include:

options.text: Volatile toxic waste such as mercury

questions.explanation: Heavy metals like Mercury and Lead should never be incinerated as they release toxic vapors into the atmosphere.
questions.hint: Think of things that become toxic gas when burned.

questions.question: Disposal of dead bodies may include which of the following methods?
questions.explanation: Cremation is a method of final disposal. Embalmment and Mummification are methods of preservation.
questions.hint: This involves burning the body.

questions.question: A person's diminished response to a drug that is the result of repeated use is best described as:
questions.explanation: Tolerance is the physiological state where the body adapts to the drug, requiring higher doses to achieve the same effect.
questions.hint: You need more of the drug to get the same 'high'.

questions.question: A stage of drug abuse characterized by use on a regular basis and in a predictable pattern is:
questions.explanation: This describes the Social/Regular use phase where consumption follows a routine but may not yet be an addiction.
questions.hint: This often happens at parties or weekends predictably.

questions.question: Drugs and substances associated with 'tripping' are:
questions.explanation: Hallucinogens (LSD, Magic Mushrooms) cause altered perceptions of reality known as 'trips'.
questions.hint: They make you hallucinate.

questions.question: Physical symptoms of drug/substance withdrawal syndrome include:
questions.explanation: Tremors (shaking) are a classic *physical* sign of withdrawal. Isolation and Irritability are psychological/behavioral.
questions.hint: Look for the physical body reaction, not the mood.

questions.question: Which of the following is consistent with the 'Step 2' approach to occupational health and safety?

options.text: Commitment to a safe work place by framing a policy
Recognizing and removing dangers using a danger identification list

questions.explanation: After establishing policy (Step 1), the next logical step is Risk Assessment/Identification (Recognizing dangers).
questions.hint: After making a policy, you must find out what the dangers are.

questions.question: Which of the following factors is NOT a risk to occupational hazard?

options.text: Predisposition not to complain about exposures

questions.explanation: Being familiar with work processes typically reduces risk through competence. Lack of knowledge increases risk.
questions.hint: Which of these actually makes you SAFER?

questions.question: Physical occupational health hazards include:
questions.explanation: Physical hazards relate to energy (Heat, Cold, Noise, Radiation). Unshielded machinery is Mechanical. Bacteria are Biological.
questions.hint: It relates to temperature.

questions.question: An industrial worker inhaled a toxic chemical. Which of the following is a possible health effect?
questions.explanation: Pneumoconiosis is a general term for lung disease caused by inhaling dusts/chemicals. Byssinosis is specific to cotton. Leptospirosis is bacterial.
questions.hint: A lung condition caused by dust/particles.

questions.question: The most appropriate method of controlling occupational health hazards at source in a road construction site during dry seasons is:
questions.explanation: Spraying water (Wet method) suppresses dust at the source, preventing it from becoming airborne.
questions.hint: How do you stop dust from flying?

questions.question: The natural history of non-communicable diseases entails:

options.text: Progression over a period of time
Ease of prevention at the community level

questions.explanation: NCDs are characterized by a slow progression over a long duration (chronic nature).
questions.hint: They happen slowly, not rapidly.

questions.question: Controlling rodents can be done by:
questions.explanation: Trapping is a mechanical method of rodent control. Use of shoes prevents jiggers/hookworm.
questions.hint: A mechanical method to catch them.

questions.question: Which one of the following is NOT a pillar of primary health care?
questions.explanation: Information, Financing, and Human Resources are health system pillars. Training TBAs is a specific activity, not a systemic pillar.
questions.hint: Which one is a specific activity rather than a system component?

questions.question: Ethical issues concerning research subjects include:
questions.explanation: Confidentiality and Privacy are rights of the research *subject*. Plagiarism and Fraud relate to the researcher's integrity.
questions.hint: This protects the identity of the people participating.

questions.question: Disadvantages of landfills include:

options.text: It is a breeding ground for infectious disease
It causes buried chemicals to leak into the soil

questions.explanation: Leachate (leaking chemicals) is a major environmental risk of landfills, contaminating groundwater.
questions.hint: Think about what happens to the groundwater.

questions.question: Match the following epidemiological terms with their definitions:

pairs.right: Disease cases in excess of normal expectancy
Constant presence of a disease in a geography

questions.explanation: Epidemic: Excess cases. Endemic: Constant presence. Holoendemic: High prevalence/intensity. Pandemic: Global spread. Morbidity: Illness.
questions.hint: Pandemic implies 'Pan' (all/wide). Endemic implies 'En' (in/local).

questions.question: Which of the following are methods of PROBABILITY sampling?
questions.explanation: Probability sampling involves random selection (Simple, Systematic, Stratified, Cluster). Snowball and Convenience are non-probability.
questions.hint: Select the methods that involve randomization.

questions.question: Identify the elements of Primary Health Care (PHC) from the list below:
questions.explanation: PHC elements include Education, Nutrition, Water/Sanitation, MCH, Immunization, etc. Advanced surgery is tertiary care.
questions.hint: Think of the basic services needed at the community level.

questions.question: Match the class of workplace hazard with the correct example:
questions.explanation: Physical (Energy), Chemical (Substances), Biological (Living organisms), Ergonomic (Body position), Psychosocial (Mental well-being).
questions.hint: Match the nature of the hazard to its category.

questions.question: Select the diseases that are classified as EMERGING (appeared for the first time or rapidly increasing):
questions.explanation: COVID-19, Ebola, and HIV are considered emerging (or recently emerged). Malaria and TB are Re-emerging (coming back).
questions.hint: Think of diseases that are relatively 'new' to the human population.

questions.question: Arrange the phases of the Disaster Management Cycle in the correct logical sequence:
questions.explanation: The cycle goes: Mitigation (Prevent) -> Preparedness (Plan) -> Response (Act during disaster) -> Recovery (Rebuild).
questions.hint: Start with what you do BEFORE the disaster happens.

questions.question: Which of the following are causes or risk factors for drug and substance abuse?
questions.explanation: Peer pressure, stress, availability, and poor guidance increase risk. Strong support is a protective factor.
questions.hint: Select the negative influences.

questions.question: Select the key features of a CLINICAL TRIAL (Experimental Study):
questions.explanation: Clinical trials involve active intervention, randomization, controls, and blinding. Observation without interference is for observational studies.
questions.hint: Experimental studies involve the researcher doing something to the subjects.

questions.question: Which of the following are major methods for preventing and controlling infectious diseases?

richContent.content: Strategies: Control aims to break the chain of transmission.

questions.explanation: Major strategies include Immunization (protect host), WASH (interrupt transmission), and Vector Control. Sedentary lifestyle is a risk factor for NCDs.
questions.hint: Select the three valid public health interventions.
